orgName.ref: Liturgica Poloniae. Katalog polskich rękopisów liturgicznych. Cz. 1: do około 1300 r.

msIdentifier.repository: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

msContents.summary: Cistercian collectar of the so-called second recension with parts of a ritual and the calendar with local obituaries; parchment (151 ff.) and paper (flyleaves and fragment: V ff. + loose paper leaf fragment); 220–226 × 155–162 mm (page size); codex comprised of quaternions (exceptions in the 1. and 9. quires); 3 sets of foliations from different periods; decorated with numerous initials (among them 2 silhouette and 2 scrollwork initials); the main text written in praegothica, mostly in 1 column with 16 lines; music notation (on ff. 7r, 145r and 146v); early modern binding (brown calfskin over wooden boards) from Poland (mid 16th c.).

msItem.note:
(1) col. Ad p<osce>nd<am> serenitatem – Ad te nos Domine clamantes exaudi, et aeris serenitatem... >< ...clementiam sentiamus
Modern pencil note: Rękopis opisany Kalendarz wydany. Zakrzewski St., Analecta Cisterciensia. Rozprawy Akad. Um. Hist. Fil. s. II tom XXIV Krk 1907 In the bottom: probatio calami (Ave Ave)
Two illegible round stamps in the middle

note.p: Original layer, includes saints and feasts typical of the Cistercian calendar, noteworthy:

[missing leaf for January]; Vitalis, Felicule, Zenonis, Com. (14 Feb.); Marie Magdalene, XII l., D [duae missae] (22 July); Christophori et Cucufati, mart., Com. (25 July); Evur- cii, ep., Com. (7 Sept.); Lamberti, ep. et mart., Com. (17 Sept.); Virginum undecim mi- lium, XII l. (21 Oct.); Cesarii, Benigni, mart. (1 Nov.)

Later additions (late 12th/13th–17th; hands H6, Ha2, Ha3, Ha4, and Ha5 possibly involved) include saints and feasts added successively according to development of the Cistercian calendar, some of them have only been introduced in certain regions/monastic centres; in some cases, the rank of the feast changed over time (e.g. Lamberti ep. et. mart, from Com to XII l.), noteworthy additions:

[missing leaf for January]; Dorothee, virg., XII l. (6 Feb.); Kasimiri conf., XII l. (4 March); Ioseph sponsi BVM, MM [duae missae] (19 March); Adalberti, ep. et mart., XII l., 2 m. (23 April); Roberti, abb., XII l. (29 April); Stanislai, ep. et mart., XII l., 2 m. (8 May); Ludgardis, virg., m. [mystica] (16 June); Translacio trium regum ad Coloniam (23 July); [Spinea] Corone Domini, XII l., 2 m. (11 Aug.); Bernardi, abb., XII l., 2 m., ser. (20 Aug.); Lodovici, conf., XII l., 1 m. (25 Aug.); Wenceslai, mart., XII l., 1 m. (28 Sept.); Dominica post Dyonisii habetur dedicatio Lydensis ecclesiae); Hadewigis (15 Oct.); Quinque fratrum Polonorum, XII l., 1 m. (12 Nov.); Katherine, XII l. (25 Nov.); Thome [Thomas Becket], ep. et mart., XII l., 2 m. (29 Dec.); Dedicacio seu consecracio ymaginis crucifixi domini nostri Ihesu Christi nec non omnium ymagi- num tabularum beate Virginis Marie semper proxima feria tercia infra octavas Ascensio- nis Domini est celebranda
Anniversaries celebrated in Ląd Abbey, added to the calendar:

anniversarium Karoli (4 Feb.); anniversarium Nycolai iudicis de Venecia... in anno III feria singulis quatuor temporibus (25 Feb.); anniversarium Wyczek heredis in Szetlewo semper quolibet anno in singulis quatuor temporibus (27 Feb.); anniversarium comitis Dobeslai (13 March); obiit dux Mescho fundator domus Landensis (15 March); Philip- pus monachus et sacerdos propter nomen Christi in Pruzia martirizatus est (4 May); anniversarium omnium monachorum noviciorum et conversorum ac monialium ordinis nostri (20 May); anno domini MCCLXXXXIIII occubuit dux Kazimirus Lanzizienzis pro ecclesia sancta (10 June)

msItem.title: Collectar with parts of a ritual

msItem.rubric: A natali Domini usque ad diem Epiphaniae (f. 13r);
Sabbato ante dominicam quae prima sequitur octavas Theophaniae (f. 17r);
Per omnes dominicas ab octava Theophaniae usque ad quadragesimam (f. 20r);
De privatis diebus in XL... Feria secunda (f. 26r);
Ordo privatis diebus tenendus usque in vigiliam Paschae (f. 36r);
Feria V in cena Domini et feria VI (f. 42r);
Ordo de privatis diebus ab octava Paschae usque ad Rogationes (f. 46v);
Privatis diebus per octavas usque ad Pentecosten (f. 53v);

support.p: Paper ( ff. I–IV, 154 ; loose paper leaf fragment):

foliation.p: The most recent one with Arabic numerals in pencil in the upper right corner of the recto side on ff. 1–151 (1–151).
The older one with Arabic numerals in pencil appears in the upper left corner of the recto side on ff. II–154 (2–154).
The oldest one in ink can be found in the middle of the upper margin of the recto side on ff. 8–25 (1–13).

supportDesc.foliation: The front leaves have Roman numerals in pen (?) (I–IV), the endleaf (f. 154) has an Arabic number in pencil (154 – foliation no. 2). The loose paper fragment has no foliation.

list.item: quire 9 is a quaternion with one smaller singleton added (f. 68).

No quire marks or catchwords. There is also a paper ternion, two folios canceled, in front of the codex (ff. I–IV) and a single folio at the back (f. 154). The paper folios were added as flyleaves in the middle of the 16th c. with the new binding.

condition.p: color: brownish / yellowish, darkened, original holes in ff. 22 (stitching holes visible), 25, 32, 80, 126, 130, 135; prepared on both sides
condition.seg: Binding and flyleaves: the bookblock is trimmed; the secondary binding is very damaged – lack of the previously existing furnishings and fastenings; darkened and dried leather on the covers with many abrasions and losses, particularly large in the spine area; blind tooling is flattened and obliterated; partly damaged endbands; minor losses of the wooden covers with characteristic small holes made by invertebrates; also paper flyleaves and adjacent parts of the bookblock expose extensive, characteristic losses caused by invertebrates; the join of the bookblock and the back cover is partly damaged; back papers are in a state of destruction: darkened, stained, weakened with extensive losses and two completely separated fragments; front flyleaves expose damages mostly of the upper margin. Front pastedown is stained, with significant losses along the edges and breakups within the whole area. The condition of the black inks of the scripts on the front papers show the ink corrosion process, especially on ff. I and II. Parchment: most parchment folios are unevenly darkened and yellowed (some brownish), indicating possible process of collagen degradation. Many folios with visible stains, some clearly caused by the action of moisture in the past. Surface dirt distributed mostly on the outer margins and outer bottom corners of the folios. Considerable losses and cracks of the parchment within the folds and outer sides of the bookblock, also within the outer bottom corners between ff. 76 and 82; some losses of the manuscript layer respectively. Inks: local abrasions of the black and red ink layers intentionally taken off by scraping, partly filled with the secondary text – including large interferences on ff. 7v, 8r, 11r, 13r, 25v, 35v, 36r, 41v, 55r, 65v, 66v, 67r–v, 71v, 73v, 74r, 75r–v, 77r, 78r, 79r–v, 86r–v, 89v, 91r, 92r, 95v, 98r, 99r, 101v, 103v, 104v, 106r, 116r; on many folios marginal additions are abraded and/or poorly legible, e.g.: ff. 1r–v, 2r, 57r; in most places the ink of the secondary additions firmly penetrated the parchment, causing the danger of ink corrosion. Initials and decoration: the painting layers of the colored initials are also partly abraded, particularly within the upper part of the folios: some parts of green and red colors are completely powdered; some red initials within the outer folios of the bookblock are also visibly darkened. Yellow colors are both faded or optionally darkened. Some of the blue initials are distinctly darkened. Green initials penetrated deeply into the parchment, crumbling or changing the color to brownish, some letters destroyed (ff. 2v, 5v) which might indicate different stages of the copper corrosion process. However, large decorated initials on ff. 7v and 42v and smaller linear initial on f. 117r remain in rather good condition. Distinctive silhouette initials on ff. 54v and 63r are unfortunately partly abraded.

layoutDesc.layout:
2-2/0/1-1/J
ff. 7r–123v, 125v–129v, 132r–151v ; written space 154 102 mm ; distance between vertical ruling 9/102/8 mm; 16 lines.

2-2-3/0/1-1/J
ff. 124r–125r, 130r–131v; written space 163 120 mm; distance between vertical ruling 8/40/7/7/50/8 mm; 16 lines.

handDesc.handNote: (H1) the main text of the collectar is written in large praegothica (second half of the 12th c.). Parts of the text in smaller praegothica can be found on ff. 62v, 137r–138v, 145r–147v. Frequent use of the ampersand, nt and st ligatures, and e caudata. No forking of ascenders, horizontal serifs instead. Letter g with two closed lobes. Double i in a form ij.
(H2) The main text of the calendar (ff. 1r–6r) is written in small praegothica (second half of the 12th c.).
(H3) The fifth column of the computus tables (f. 6v) is written in small praegothica (13th c.).
(H4) The list of commemorative antiphons (f. 7r) is written in small praegothica (13 th c.).
(H5) Text on the added smaller leaf (f. 68r) is written in large praegothica (second half of the 12th c.).

(H6) Added text on ff. 118v–119v is written in northern textualis formata (14th c.). There are many marginal and interlinear additions and corrections by several medieval and early modern hands. Some of them can be distinguished:
(Ha1) Marginal additions in red praegothica: ff. 105v, 110r, 111r–v, 112v, 113r–v (probably slightly later than the original text).
(Ha2) Longer additions in praegothica filling the lower margin, erased and hardly visible: ff. 57r–58r, 76r.
(Ha3) Short marginal additions in praegothica, in decorative frames ff. 97v, 98v, 101r, 101v, 104r, 107r (13 th c.).
(Ha4) Short marginal or interlinear additions in northern textualis libraria with paragraph signs extended into decorative frames: ff. 70r, 86r, 93r–v, 99r, 101r, 104v (14th c.).

(Ha5) Longer corrections and additions by an early modern hand throughout the entire manuscript, sometimes the original text is crossed out (e.g. f. 9v), sometimes the corrections are made over the erased original text (e.g. f. 13r), (16th/17th c.).
(Ha6) In some places a new liturgical text was added on the erased original text by a later (probably early modern) hand imitating the original script: ff. 60v, 61r, 95v, 96r.

musicNotation.p: (1) original layer (ff. 145r, 146v): German-French unheightened neumes. The set of signs is characteristic of the Cistercian usage, though the neumes are not placed on lines. The set of signs also contains the special German neumes (quilisma, pressus), which suggests that it was written relatively early and in Germany. Both forms of clivis (acute and rectangular) are present, with the latter occurring only in a compound with the previous punctum at the same height. Noteworthy are both forms of cephalicus (French and German). Although the neumes were written without lines, the “2”-shaped custos (an integral part of the Cistercian notation) is present in the fourth line of the antiphon for the deceased, inc. Clementissime domine qui pro nostra (f. 145r). This antiphon is the only chant with full musical notation provided. Only the initial formulas appear in the two other chants (f. 146v). (2) later additions (f. 7r): messine neumes (heightened), 13th c.

additions.note:
ff. I–IV Additions Front pastedown:
17h c.
col. Ad poscendam serenitatem – Ad te nos Domine clamantes exaudi, et aeris serenitatem clementiam sentiamus.
Rękopis opisany Kalendarz wydany. Zakrzewski St., Analecta Cisterciensia. Rozprawy Akad. Um. Hist. Fil. s. II tom XXIV Krk 1907 in the bottomAve Ave Two illegible round stamps in the middle

note.p: Within the manuscript there is a loose fragment of a paper leaf with a part of a letter in Polish from the early modern period, presumably of the 16 th c.:
M[ilos]cziwi x. opaczie Lenczky <m>oy Mcziwi panie sluzbi swe ssercza [illegible] <me>ego Mcziwego pana [illegible]

note.title: Early Modern additions throughout the entire manuscript
note.p: On most folios (apart from ff. 118v–151v) numerous additions by the same late 17th c. cursive hand (cf. ff. Ir and IIr) with incipits or whole texts of collects and chapters which adjust the content to post-Tridentine Cistercian rite edited for the first time in Breviarium cistercium iuxta ritum romanum (1656). The original content is often scraped off (e.g. ff. 25v, 55r, 66v, 67v, 75r, 77r, 99r, 116r) or crossed out (e.g. ff. 16r, 20r, 23v–24r, 35v, 55v–56r, 91v–92r). Similar additions by other 17th c. hands on ff. 31v, 71v, 76r, 105v; sometimes written on erased text and imitating gothic script (ff. 60v–61r, 95v–96r).

binding.p: Binding Dating and dimensions: mid 16th c., workshop of Poznań (?); 155–166 × 230–246 mm, 55–58 mm (block with binding). General character: brown calfskin over wooden boards with blind tooling decoration. Pastedown, flyleaves: single paper pastedowns which have been folded in hook guards around the paper endleaf quires in quarto. The stabs of pastedowns glued to the first and the last folios of the manuscript. Sewing: sewn on four raised double supports made of hempen cords. Spine lining: the spine rounded and lined with parchment strips. Endbands: worked on the edge of parchment strips of a head- and a tail-lining with triple linen thread in two colors. Edges: trimmed and undecorated. Boards and their attachment: beech boards beveled from the inner face along the whole length of the free edges. The beveling interrupted at places of intended furnishings and fastenings. Covering: smoothed brown calfskin. Decoration: on the upper cover, triple fillet creates two-line compartment borders to a central panel. The outermost frame is decorated with baluster-like ornament and on the inner border and the central panel three floral stamps are used. The impressions of a fleuron stamp creates the cross in the middle of the central panel. The title “COLLE CTARIUS” is stamped in the lower part of the inner border. On the lower cover the ornamental roll creates a single border of a central panel decorated with impressions of three kinds of floral stamps. 212 Descriptio et traditio. Potencjał projektów badawczych Liturgica Poloniae: Katalog polskich... Codices et fragmenta. Średniowieczny kodeks rękopiśmienny w aspekcie historycznego trwania Fastenings and furnishings: one hook-clasp fastening was used, although the covers were prepared to attach two fasteners. Impressions of metal furnishings stylized around the mid16th c. in the corners of both covers are visible.

origin.origDate: The manuscript was produced in the Cistercian scriptorium in the Cologne area in the third quarter of the 12 th c., presumably in Altenberg (a mother monastery of Ląd) which – according to the Order’s rules – had an obligation to equip the newly founded house with a collectar. The dating of the manuscript is argued based on the lack of the formulary for the feast of St Bernard (added after the temporal cycle, already after the completion of the codex), and the originally lacking commemoration of St Thomas Becket in the calendar, which was added by a different hand. Furthermore, the feast of Mary Magdalene has still a lower rank than that introduced to the Order in 1175. Moreover, in the calendar, there is an addition of the translation of Three Kings to Cologne, which occurred on July 13, 1164. It was most probable that the addition was inserted while the manuscript was still around Cologne, perhaps in Altenberg abbey, whence the monks came to Ląd at the end of the 12 th c.

source.p: Altenberg (?)–Ląd–Poznań–Kraków–?– London–New York–New Haven Soon after its production in the Cologne area, the manuscript was used in the Cistercian monastery of Ląd (est. ca. 1145) in Greater Poland, as attested by the locally inserted obituary additions in the calendar. The early modern additions to the manuscript, modifying its liturgical content according to the liturgical reforms after the Council of Trent, suggest persistent usage of the collectar in the monastery until at least the 17th c. In the 19th c., the manuscript was in Poznań, Biblioteka seminaryjna, as attested by numerous modern stamps (e.g., front guard paper folio, f. IIIr). The collectar was not included by Arkadiusz Lisiecki in his catalogue of manuscripts from Poznań, Biblioteka seminaryjna, published in 1905, because at the beginning of the 20th c. the manuscript was already in Kraków, Biblioteka Polskiej Akademii Umiejętności (PAU). According to Stanisław Zakrzewski, who published on the collectar’s calendar in 1907, the manuscript was handed to the PAU library as a deposit. Władysław Semkowicz (d. 1949) could have been the last scholar who had direct access to the collectar and published the analysis of the manuscript in his posthumously edited Paleografia łacińska (1951) upon which he worked during World War II. However, as reported by Hieronim Feicht in 1966, the manuscript was lost from Kraków during World War II. In 1996 the codex was listed in the auction catalogue of Sotheby’s, presumably purchased by H.P. Kraus (New York). In 1999 the collectar was sold by H.P. Kraus to Beinecke Library (New Haven) thanks to the Albert H. Childs Fund.

body.p: Ecclesiam tuam domine benignus illustra ut beati Iohannis Apostoli tui et euangeliste illuminata doctrinis ad dona perueniat sempiterna. Per.
